title: 115_hr4359
content: The "Tribal HUD-VASH Act of 2017" provides rental assistance for homeless or at-risk Indian veterans. Section 8(o)(19) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to include an Indian veterans housing rental assistance program for eligible Indian veterans who are homeless or at risk of homelessness and residing in or near an Indian area. Eligible recipients can receive a grant. The amended Section 8(o)(19) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 now includes an Indian veterans housing rental assistance program for eligible Indian veterans who are homeless or at risk of homelessness in or near an Indian area. Recipients eligible for a grant under the Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996. The terms 'Indian' and 'Indian area' are defined in relevant legislation. The Indian veterans housing rental assistance program under the amended Section 8(o)(19) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 defines terms like 'Indian veteran' and 'tribal organization' as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The Secretary must allocate at least 5 percent of rental assistance funds for program implementation. The Secretary will provide rental assistance and supported housing for eligible Indian veterans in conjunction with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, modeling the Program on existing rental assistance programs. The Secretary, in collaboration with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, may make necessary modifications to facilitate the use of the Program by eligible recipients to serve eligible Indian veterans. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in consultation with Indian tribes and eligible recipients, may make modifications to facilitate the use of the Program by eligible recipients to serve Indian veterans. The Secretary will provide rental assistance and administrative costs to eligible recipients based on need, administrative capacity, and other criteria established in consultation with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will administer rental assistance under the Program in accordance with the Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996, with grantees required to submit reports and provide information to assess effectiveness. The Secretary, in coordination with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, consults with eligible recipients and tribal organizations to design the Program for effective delivery of rental assistance and supportive services to Indian veterans. The Director of the Indian Health Service will assist the Secretary or the Secretary of Veterans Affairs in implementing the Program. The Secretary has the authority to waive or modify requirements for rental assistance under certain conditions. The Secretary may waive or specify alternative requirements for rental assistance under the Program if necessary for effective delivery to eligible Indian veterans, excluding labor standards or environmental regulations. Reporting is required every 5 years. Every 5 years, the Secretary, in coordination with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Director of the Indian Health Service, conducts a review of the Program's implementation and submits a report to specific committees.
